articles.title: MARCH 1985
articles.summary: This document outlines upcoming astronomy events for March and April 1985, highlighted by a March 30th general meeting featuring NASA Project Manager Nick Vojvodich discussing the Galileo/Jupiter mission. Other activities include Messier Marathons, indoor star parties, and field expeditions for astronomical observation. The schedule also notes various board meetings and concludes with Astronomy Day on April 27th.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document contains classified advertisements for used astronomy equipment. Featured items include a new Celestron 5.5" f/1.85 Schmidt camera with accessories and an excellent condition Celestron 8 telescope bundled with binoculars, both offered at significant discounts by John Gleason. The ads highlight the equipment's suitability for observing Halley's Comet.

articles.title: TUCSON 85' BY: DAVID LEVEY
articles.summary: The article announces the 1985 Astronomical Society convention, 'Tucson 85', scheduled from June 8th to 22nd. The five-day event will feature tours of Kitt Peak and the Multiple Mirror Telescope (MMT), observing sessions in Tucson's clear June skies, paper sessions, and a contest for astrophotographs and observing projects. Attendees are encouraged to register early for limited tours.

articles.title: UNIVERSE MAGAZINE
articles.summary: UNIVERSE MAGAZINE is a radio program on KCBS AM that offers listeners direct access to scientists and their discoveries through an interview/call-in format. The program covers a wide array of topics, from dinosaurs to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, and has been on air for nineteen months. It broadcasts on Saturday evenings at 8:00 PM.

articles.title: BY: STEVE GOTTLIEB
articles.summary: Steve Gottlieb's article presents detailed visual observations of several lesser-known NGC galaxies located within the constellation Cancer. Conducted in January 1985 using 17.5" and 24.5" reflectors, the report describes each galaxy's appearance, magnitude, and notable features, often referencing photographic data for comparison. The observations highlight challenging deep-sky objects accessible to large amateur telescopes.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: John Gleason thanks members for phone numbers, announces the 1985 Members List and renewal availability, and addresses issues with late Ephemeris delivery caused by bulk mail sorting and a recent computer crash. He promotes the upcoming 5th Annual Astronomical Auction on May 4th and requests star party reports. The article also mentions a headline about 107 events observed during a graze expedition.

articles.title: BY: SHIELA MACDOUGAL, SJAA
articles.summary: This article recounts Shiela MacDougal's experience attempting to observe a lunar occultation of the star Gamma Globulin on February 20th. Despite meticulous planning and a trek to the graze site, heavy cloud cover and the bright full Moon severely hampered visibility, preventing her from seeing the target star. The observation team nonetheless recorded cloud passages, and the author, though disappointed, eagerly anticipates future astronomical expeditions.

articles.title: ATM coatings
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for telescope mirror coating services provided by ATM Coatings. They specialize in aluminum coatings with a silicon monoxide over-coating for primary and secondary mirrors, offering various sizes at specified prices. The service also includes removal of old coatings for an additional fee and details on shipping.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMIVAL ASSOCIATION 1985 MEMBERSHIP
articles.summary: This document is the 1985 membership roster for the San Jose Astronomical Association. It lists individual members by name, along with their addresses, city, state, zip code, and phone numbers. The list appears to be a directory of the association's members from that year.

articles.title: D Section
articles.summary: This document is a directory listing, providing contact information for individuals. It includes names, street addresses, cities, zip codes, and phone numbers, primarily for residents in various cities across California, with a strong concentration in the San Jose and broader Bay Area.

articles.title: Directory Listing
articles.summary: This document is a directory listing providing names, addresses, and phone numbers for numerous individuals. The majority of the listed contacts reside in various cities across California's Bay Area, with a few entries from other states like Arizona and one international location in England.

articles.title: Directory Listing
articles.summary: This document is a directory listing of individuals, providing their names, street addresses, cities, states, zip codes, and phone numbers. The entries primarily feature individuals located in various cities across California, with a few entries from Arizona and Washington. Some entries have missing phone numbers or partial name information.

articles.title: S Section
articles.summary: This document is an alphabetical directory listing of individuals whose last names start with 'S' (and some subsequent letters like 'T', 'V', 'W', 'Z'). It provides their full name, mailing address, and phone number, with many entries located in various cities across California.

articles.title: New Members and Late Renewals
articles.summary: This document lists new members and individuals who have completed late renewals, providing their names, addresses, and phone numbers. The entries include individuals such as Logan M. Belleville, Dave W. Lambson, and Dave Pura, primarily residing in the San Jose, CA area.

articles.title: DOORS WILL OPEN AT 2:00 PM
articles.summary: An astronomical equipment swap meet and sale will take place at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, starting at 2:00 PM. Attendees are encouraged to buy and sell a wide array of astronomical items, including telescopes, eyepieces, mounts, books, and camera equipment. This event is highlighted as one of the biggest and most enjoyable astronomical gatherings in the Bay Area.

articles.title: PRE-REGISTRATION INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document provides pre-registration information for the 5th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, an event organized by the SJAA to fund public astronomy education. It details instructions for sellers to pre-register their astronomical and telescope-making items by mail, including item descriptions, minimum bids, and SJAA's percentage of the sale. The article also includes directions to the auction venue, event timings, payment options, and a registration form.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article reports no new comet discoveries or recoveries in the past month, maintaining the current tally at 13. It notes the visibility of several comets including Levy-Rudenko, Shoemaker (1984f), and the fainter Periodic Comets Tschuchinshan (1984e) and Schaumasse (1984m). Additionally, the author announces the availability of a new 115-page booklet detailing amateur comet discoveries from 1975 to 1984 for $8.00 ppd.

articles.title: DATE R.A. (1950) DEC. ELONG. MAG.
articles.summary: This document provides ephemeris data for Comet Levy-Rudenko (1984t) and Comet Shoemaker (1984f) for late February through early April. It notes that Comet Levy-Rudenko is dimming and offers a final viewing opportunity, while Comet Shoemaker is expected to brighten in May as it moves further south.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND
articles.summary: This article provides an update on Halley's Comet, detailing its brightening trend and celestial position near Orion and Taurus, along with ephemeris data for March and early April. It includes technical specifications such as orbital elements and brightness estimates, noting its variability and future visibility. The piece also encourages participation in the International Halley Watch and lists various resources for comet enthusiasts, including publications and contact information.

articles.title: BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article provides updates on various space activities in early 1985, detailing Space Shuttle missions 51-C and 51-E, including delays, launches, and payload specialists. It also covers the expansion of the orbiter fleet and future Discovery missions. Internationally, Japan launched a mission to Halley's Comet, and European nations approved a 10-year space program featuring the Ariane 5 launcher and participation in the U.S. space station, while NASA initiated new projects like the Extreme Ultraviolet Explorer and proposed a Mars mission in its budget.
